fields.Title of Contribution: Comparison of Computational Molecular Dynamics and Electrophysiology Studies of alpha-Conotoxin Peptide Binding and Bioactivity
fields.Description/Abstract: Neurodegenerative disorders, including Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s disease, result from the degradation of the central nervous system, particularly in the functionality of cholinergic and dopaminergic systems. The α3β2-nAChR isoform is a model receptor system for the α6α4β2β3-nAChR isoform shown to degrade in Parkinson’s patients. It has been previously reported that binding of ligand agonists to the α3β2-nAChR isoform, such as nicotine, trigger the biological response of neuronal receptor up-regulation and reduction of proteasomal subunit degradation. In order to identify ligands that induce a favorable biological response, this study investigates the relative binding energies of three α-conotoxins (α-CTxs): native α-CTx MII, and two mutant variants, MII[E11A] and MII[N5R:E11A:H12K]. Two-electrode voltage clamp electrophysiology was used to determined IC50 values for α-CTx MII and mutants. The IC50 values were 0.425, 0.996, and 7.75 nM for α-CTx MII, MII[E11A], and MII[N5R:E11A:H12K], respectively. Molecular dynamics simulations were applied to these systems to explore the energetics and dynamics of α-CTx interaction with nAChRs. The MII[N5R:E11A:H12K] mutant had a relative binding free energy (∆∆Gbind) of -7.29 kcal mol-1 compared to the relative binding free energy of MII[E11A]  which was 1.93 kcal mol-1. Despite the greater predicted binding affinity for the MII[N5R:E11A:H12K] mutant, TEV experiments showed that this ligand only induced approximately 60% blockage of α3β2-nAChR.
